text:
FIRST VIOLATION OF THE LAW OF CONSERVATION OF ENERGY (MECHANICAL VERSION)  
---------------------------------------------  
ANSWER THE TWO SIMPLE QUESTIONS BELOW.
---------------------------------------------
ASKING OUR TWO SIMPLE QUESTIONS FOR THE 5TH TIME.
--------------------------------------------  
1) Consider carefully and thoroughly (and many times!) the link https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xX14NK8GrDY      .
--------------------------------------------  
2) Having in mind the link  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xX14NK8GrDY      assume that:  
a) Ma = 1 kg;  
b) Mb = 4 kg; the value of Mb can be either increased or decreased as many times as you want;  
c) V1 = 1m/s = const;  
d) Ffr. = force of friction inside the zigzag channels = 0.0000001 N; the latter can be further decreased as many times as you want;     
e) N = number of zigzags = 10; the value of N can be either increased or decreased as many times as you want;  
f) Shapes of the zigzags = sinusoids; the latter can be replaced by any other curve patterns.  
--------------------------------------------  
3) It is evident that if V2 = 0.6 m/s and if V3 = 0.1 m/s, then (a) the law of conservation of linear momentum is valid and (b) the law of conservation of mechanical energy is invalid.  
--------------------------------------------  
4) It is evident that if V2 = 0.8 m/s and if V3 = 0.3 m/s, then (a) the law of conservation of linear momentum is invalid and (b) the law of conservation of mechanical energy is valid.  
--------------------------------------------  
5) It is evident that both (a) the law of conservation of linear momentum and (b) the law of conservation of mechanical energy are invalid simultaneously in this special particular zigzag case, which is described in the link  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xX14NK8GrDY      .
--------------------------------------------  
SO  ANSWER THE TWO SIMPLE QUESTIONS BELOW.
--------------------------------------------  
QUESTION 1: V2 = ? (How many meters per second is V2 equal to?)  
QUESTION 2: V3 = ? (How many meters per second is V3 equal to?)  
--------------------------------------------  
LOOKING FORWARD TO YOUR TWO ANSWERS FOR THE 5TH TIME.  
=============================== 
===============================  
===============================
===============================  
=============================== 
=============================== 
SECOND VIOLATION OF THE LAW OF CONSERVATION OF ENERGY (ELECTRIC VERSION)  
------------------------------------------------------------  
ANSWER THE FOUR SIMPLE QUESTIONS BELOW.
----------------------------------------------------------
LOOKING FORWARD TO YOUR FOUR ANSWERS FOR THE 5TH TIME. 
-----------------------------------------------------------  
1) Consider carefully and thoroughly (and many times!) the link  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BAydFMDKj2Y   
--------------------------------------------------------  
2) Having in mind the link https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BAydFMDKj2Y     answer the four simple questions below.  
--------------------------------------------------------  
QUESTION 1: What is the value of the electric energy, which is consumed by the electrolyte, that is, how many Joules of electric energy does the electrolyte consume?  
QUESTION 2: What is the value of the Joule's heat, which is generated by the electrolyte, that is, how many Joules of Joule's heat does the electrolyte generate?  
QUESTION 3: What is the mass of the released hydrogen, that is, how many kilograms of hydrogen does the electrolyte release while electrolysis takes place?  
QUESTION 4: What is the value of the heat, which is generated by burning/exploding of the released hydrogen, that is, how many Joules of heat is generated by burning/exploding of the released hydrogen?  
--------------------------------------------------------
ANSWER THE FOUR SIMPLE QUESTIONS ABOVE.
LOOKING FORWARD TO YOUR FOUR ANSWERS FOR THE 5TH TIME.

Mrs Richards " I paid for a room with a view !"  
Basil: (pointing to the lovely view) "That is Torquay, Madam."  
Mrs Richards: "It's not good enough!"  
Basil: "May I ask what you were expecting to see out of a Torquay hotel bedroom window? Sydney Opera House, perhaps? the Hanging Gardens of Babylon? Herds of wildebeest sweeping majestically past?..."  
Mrs Richards: "Don't be silly! I expect to be able to see the sea!" 
Basil: "You can see the sea, it's over there between the land and the sky."  
Mrs Richards: "I'm not satisfied. But I shall stay. But I expect a reduction."  
Basil: "Why?! Because Krakatoa's not erupting at the moment ?

text:
This year I planted 3 fruit trees on my property to add to my already 15 fruit and nut trees. I still have 6 evergreen trees to plant in autumn along with two flowering trees and I want to add 5 more fruit tree plus more bushes for my wild rabbits and birds to play in. Basically‚Ä¶..I want a mini forest. 
My dad says I‚Äôm a lot like my grandpa, while many neighbors hate to see weeds and wildlife eating their hard work I am fascinated by the wild flowers and bunnies that come to eat. My grandpa in Mexico used to pay to clean a spring every single year so wild animals and his pigs could play in the water, everyone called him a lunatic for paying and not using it himself but he said it was totally worth it. Unlike everyone else‚Äôs dry land tho, his was always overflowing with water and food. Dad said it was his generosity and that his lands thanked him back by never going dry. A lot of native teachings got lost and my grandpa learned the most from his uncle who just like him learned to love the land and respect the animals there. My parents and I want to make our home turn into a food forest, I hope we can also get solar panels soon too. 
A tree offers clean air, shade, food, shelter for animals and it‚Äôs beautiful so I don‚Äôt see problems with more‚Ä¶.there was once so many more.

text:
Please Take 2 mins to read my comment and givt me your opinions about it. Thank you.






Well the best way to counter global warming crisis is to bring people out of poverty... We know that cost of production of energy through renewable sources is way higher (wind and solar) whereas producing energy through thermal plants and fossil fuels is way cheaper.... 

Since 36% of worlds population lives under extreme poverty (existantial crisis), they won't be able to afford the renewable energy production ... Not only this, it can also cause market inflation which can lead to millions of death and collapse of various governments and civil wars...

Hence first we will have to make sure that we bring a certain amount of people out of poverty so that our societies do not collapse.. for this you will need to create infrastructures which provides skill and education to the poor so that they can start earning decent wage... One way of doing this is to build schools , factories and manufacturing units for employment , skill development centers etc which can be funded by governments... And to build this infrastructure you will need more land ... And for that you will have to clear more forest and encroach river and sea bads ( which can damage environment for short term but will be positive in the long run)


Africa is the poorest continent ... So you will have to clear forests to bring infrastructural development to provide employment to the people so that they get a good earning ... And to do so , you will nead land , and for land you would need to clear forests...

Please state your opinions.

text:
Red and silver maples grow plenty fast. so do popular trees. Fig trees grow well even in arid environments. The super carbon killer though is brown alga that grows in the ocean and puts trees to shame and can even be grown as food.

That being said if you REALLY wanted to make a difference you would build ocean channels from the ocean to midland areas that are very arid to bring water to the area and encourage plant growth and cool down these hotbeds. The Sahara dessert used to have such a channel back when it was a tropical jungle before the Younger Dryas incident 12,000 plus years ago until a major tidal waved buried it under sand from the Mediterranean.

text:
Very glad that this video covered that it's not simple enough to just plant trees. It matters what type of tree, if it's native and a summation of what the consequences might be.
Lots of reforestation doesn't even work. Ecosystems are complicated and try to balance themselves out.

Hands down, our biggest issue is fossil fuels, mainly through transportation and creation of products. 
We shouldn't of taken something that had been in the earth for thousands of years and just start burning it and putting it into the air. Actions always have consequences.

Your personal carbon foot print is a fart in a hurricane compared to corporations and nations use for industries and transportation.

While it helps to do your part, we're not going to get anywhere if the burden is on the general public, because we're not the ones making one use plastics, we're not the ones producing various luxury/superfelous goods, nor are we the ones forcing truck drivers and planes to carry all kinds of cargo.

Biggest foot print is corporations by a long shot and they are more than happy to have people thinking their personal carbon foot print should be in spot light instead of them. 

Even if everyone reduced their usage, if corporations aren't forced to change, it won't help. Similar to the meat vs vegan debate. Farming is bad for the environment, whether you are farming veggies and fruits or meat. Vegan would save some time, but it doesn't at all fix the problem. Frutis and veggies are also extremely tempermental often and their transportation costs a lot in ways of emitting carbon. 
Getting an avocado is probably worse than buying local meat if it avocado isn't native.

text:
It will be really good if there are more number of trees and plants. We should welcome it. We should plant more and more trees to correct the folly  which humans made since the dawn of civilisation. But it may be surprising to note that even if these activities go beyond certain limits,  it may result in adverse effects,  according to environmentalists.  They say that Balance should be maintained in every activity.  I read that some scientific studies reveal this surprising fact, taking into account the substances trees emit  into the atmosphere. It may look strange rather. Also only after the dawn of agriculture, digging the earth, many changes took place on this planet. As long as Nature adjusts itself, everything will go normal if not very smooth.  For billions of years  In the history of earth, whether humans protected earth ?  Whether humans were sowing the seeds ?  How all these different forms of trees came  into existence?   Also there was nobody on this planet  to nurture the trees,   to apply fertilizers/insecticides, to remove so-called waste items or to reap the benefits of getting final outputs by plucking  the fruits. Automatic recycling took place without any intervention Everything went on smoothly through nature's own methods of work itself  and by birds, elephants, by transferring seeds  from one place to another and by monkeys by throwing them through their movements. Also it was done  by other creatures like squirrels.
Just imagine !   But it remains to be seen whether  such large amount of human intervention and their over-enthusiasm  regarding protecting nature will yield good and desired results. Nature only protects us.  Mother Nature is the boss. We are Nature's slaves only. We can only rever nature by shunning our egoistic  attitude and  by not abusing our environment to the fullest possible extent by handling plastic items, etc in a judicial manner. That is why our forefathers worshipped trees and other natural elements throughout the globe.       V. GIRIPRASAD (68)
author: Rajesh Giriprasad

text:

author: rhino015

text: ¬†@rhino015¬† I'm not being pessimistic saying that. I am aware that algae and cyanobacteria contribute the most to carbon fixation. It was just me trying to sink in the fact that a billion hectares worth of tree planting covers for a little over 15% of what we dump in every year. The sheer scale of such replantation would still make it hugely helpful, obviously however it is too impractical and I think I was romanticizing the Environment Activism side of it
author: bhavya

text: ¬†@Aaron B¬† I don't think you understand, humanity will have to make huge sacrifices if we want to survive. Sacrifices people aren't willing to make. Especially the people in power
author: Mike M

text: I would agree that this is due to our overpopulation issue. We need to understand that there is only so many ressources and we have been living above what nature can offer us for a while already, it is all due to science that we can keep this up. If the population world wide were to keep climbing the way it does however, there would eventually come a point where nothing would work anymore and people would die in the most brutal ways (well, it sadly happens even now in some parts of the world...). We should try to keep population numbers steady at least, which means not having 10 children would be a good idea. Many countries are getting there.
author: Kubey

text:
¬†@Kubey¬† yeah it seems to be a trend that the most developed countries have low birth rates and the least have the highest. Not sure if that means that we can reduce population growth by raising poor countries to economic prosperity. Or maybe it‚Äôs a cultural thing that somehow goes hand in hand with the other factors. 

Edit: interesting to think that on the one hand we ‚Äúshould‚Äù try to keep population numbers down in order to help fix lots of huge problems. Yet on the other hand we spend a crazy amount of resources trying to save people‚Äôs lives and extend their lives and let them have more kids etc. And that is considered one of the most noble causes imaginable. When you think about it there‚Äôs a bit of a conflict between those two causes technically. Almost as if lowering the priority of saving and extending lives could be a logical way to help with the environmental issues. Save money and fix the environment. Win win from that isolated narrow perspective. But I guess to be fair we value humans above all else. Just where do u draw that line? Would the 1 child policy applied globally be a moral thing to do? Ppl think that‚Äôs abhorrent as well due to it being against human rights. So it seems that the general view is human needs outweigh those of the environment
author: rhino015

text: That's not discounting what is already being captured by the rest of the forests and other means. This is total emissions, not excess emissions. Taking 1/6 off the table is huge.
author: Talyn Edmonton

text:
¬†@Talyn Edmonton¬† not to be the bad guy here but I shouldn't need to emphasize that's this was a mostly romanticized comment and I did say a sixth of our emissions and not the excess emissions. to be fair, apart from respiration and decomposition of organic matter, nearly all emissions by humans are "excess".
sorry if that came out as rude but that's my stand
author: bhavya

text:
¬†@bhavya¬† how do you define excess? What would you be willing to go without in order to eliminate the excess? I think the reality is that we can‚Äôt realistically go back to the Stone Age. And we likely wouldn‚Äôt be much better off if we did. Imagine every single person burning wood every night to stay warm, rising billions of horses a short distance from their homes where everything everyone needs has to be manufactured within a horse riding distance away. The lack of technology and availability of services, knowledge, and medicines etc would cost millions of lives as well. It‚Äôs hard to really paint a realistic scenario where we can slash our ‚Äúexcess‚Äù emissions without it costing lives. Not to say we can‚Äôt improve what we do. But giving up cars, technology, electronics, air conditioning, cities etc isn‚Äôt it. 

Buying stuff we don‚Äôt need just out of boredom, and buying cheap things and replacing them frequently rather than buying something that will last for decades and do the job would help. Disposable appliances and lawn mowers etc these days are the worst. You buy any of those things from a generation ago and u can maintain them and keep them working for life
author: rhino015

text:
¬†@rhino015¬† i am very much against the notion that modernization is a bad thing or that we must ban all such activities all of a sudden. also excess is basically more than the natural cycle, excess greenhouse emissions for instance, would be an increase in the greenhouse gas levels in the atmosphere as compared to the levels that were, say pre- industrialization, not to say there wasn't any before humans. it cannot be more flipping obvious we can't go back to the way it was, and I agree we shouldn't. I have mentioned this a  million times over and I say it again, a utopian solution, like the one, say, Greta Thunberg has in mind is unreasonable and insane, and my original comment was just a little romanticized statement.

really hope this doesn't strike up another controversy in the replies
author: bhavya

text: ¬†@bhavya¬† Humans and human behavior evolved to work with nature. In small communities, especially during the Pre Classical era, human activity allows nature to thrive. In that regard, we are no different than any other creature. Where we went wrong is in our excesses, and most of those are not due to the average person going about their lives. We have misplaced guilt and are being fooled into thinking it's all of our fault, when it is mostly a very small minority that doesn't care what ruin their profit brings. We can and should do our part to reduce our own footprints, but we also need to bring the big polluters to task instead of beating ourselves up for taking longer showers.
author: Talyn Edmonton

text: ¬†@Talyn Edmonton¬† mention one line where I implied it's the common man's fault. all I mean is we need to be aware of it. these big pressure groups are not going to stop by themselves yk
author: bhavya

text:
¬†@bhavya¬† "Emissions by man are excess"
that implies all of us in general. I say that is false.
I know fully well that they wont stop by themselves, but here is the rub...

The more that the average person does to curb their own usage gives the governments permission to "Wait and see" the outcome. In the meantime, the main culprits get a pass to continue to do what they want and the populace is satisfied that something is being done... even though it isn't. 
The single plastic use ban is good, but its not the single plastic use items causing the big issues... its fishing industry waste and improperly disposed of nylon nets. Or cruise ships saving a buck by discarding into the sea. 
Sure some places, like Paris, needed to have this addressed, but instead, they ban it around the world because everyone got triggered by a turtle with a straw in it's nose, and call it good... meanwhile, the main culprits keep doing what they are doing without real penalty.
author: Talyn Edmonton

text:
¬†@Talyn Edmonton¬† okay look, with all due respect, you need not nitpick lines out of context. it is evident that line was in context of humanity as a whole. Obviously most emissions by humans are *excess*, not to say they're significant or anything. it is the bulk that makes it a problem. Nature can handle these changes to an extent but the sheer rate at which, say emissions are being dumped it way too high and to beleive that it's too high and mighty of us to think that we can affect nature is naive and just straight wrong.
Of course it's the corporations and big industries that cause almost all of this pollution but you know what enables them to keep producing this stuff? demand. I'm not saying the supply chain can be crippled so easily, the governments and the corporations have a huge HUGE part in it but we can't just take all of the blame off of our shoulders and shove it up someone else's vault.
this does, by no means imply that we must give up all and everything immediately and go back to the caveman ways but the situation is actually a lot lot worse than most people are aware. you may be a well informed person, you seem to be but you gotta pause for a while and actually read what I'm saying, my guy.
cheers.
author: bhavya

text: I don't know about that but it is naive to think technology is going to solve climate change. In fact, one of our best tools to fight it is simply preserving forests. If we can't do that simple thing, which should require almost no effort at all if it weren't for external factors, what makes one think inventing new technology is gonna do it? They're expensive and have logistic problems that would never make them ideal. Also, we don't have the time to wait for something like that lol, climate change is already happening.

text: Plants reach an optimal level of carbon sequestration. Past that optimum, selective harvest and replanting with sequestration of the harvested woody mass by pyrolysis to biochar used for terra preta is the superior path. With selective harvest, forests can be made more hospitable to fauna and to mixed flora. Collecting slash from harvest and windfall and natural die off reduces exposure to extreme wildfire weather. Displacing fossil fuels with biofuel from this virtuous cycle pays off in lower transfer of carbon from lithosphere to atmosphere. Especially toward the west coasts of continents, superforest rain shields buffer extremes of precipitation pattern changes, reducing desertification, drought, erosion and flood.

text: ¬†@Albert Su¬†  It‚Äôs true that it‚Äôs corporations who do the the worst of the pollution, deforestation, habitat destruction, etc. but we can‚Äôt just sit by and let it happen. One thing we can do is vote with our money (give money to companies who are truly concerned with sustainability, and don‚Äôt fall for greenwashing). We can also make changes to our native environment as best we can - One town, for example, returned life to their ricer by replanting the riverbank. The soil got trapped by the roots of the trees, the bank stopped eroding, the water cleared up due to lack of sediment, so the small fish came back, then the bigger ones, then a couple of birds that preyed on the fish began to appear again... Yes this only occurred on a small scale, in that one area, but imagine if everyone started to do things like that?

author: ExDee Wobblum

text: ¬†@ExDee Wobblum¬† The glorification of the Amazon as the earth's lungs is very misleading and could be dangerous. According to science, the Amazon contributes 6% of the earth's oxygen and if we were to lose the Amazon completely, you would hardly notice the difference in oxygen supply. Correct information is always empowering. If it's more oxygen the earth needs, there are plant species that produce the most oxygen growing elsewhere which isn't necessarily the Amazon.
author: Miss Drey

text:
¬†@Miss Drey¬† The difference in 6% oxygen saturation is the difference between feeling normal and able to do fitness and feeling light-headed at rest if you have existing conditions or feeling faint under heavy exertion

Ultimately, the Amazon is being burned to fuel the fires of capitalism. So why not extol the virtues of the abused seas as well as the Amazon Rainforest, because ultimately they're both being ruined by the same forces.
author: ExDee Wobblum

text:
¬†@ExDee Wobblum¬† The same way you're trusting this science is the same way you should trust the science that says you won't notice. I also don't think you understood what Augustin and I were saying which essentially is, people are misinformed. I would like to point out again that I said if it is more oxygen the world needs, we need to be focusing more on the sea and where the other 24% of oxygen supply comes from which I'm sure most people, myself included aren't really sure.

This is by no means not saying, let's not save the Amazon forest because there are so many other reasons why the Amazon is vital but, I repeat, people should be informed accordingly because misinformation can be dangerous. For example, if more people knew that most of their oxygen comes from the sea, do you not think there would be more effort to save the ocean?

Noone is saying don't save the Amazon, I am saying inform people accordingly because the more people know, the better position they are in to act. It's like how long we've been misinformed that trees will solve the carbon problem when actually planting trees is just creating a carbon sink which is a temporary solution.
author: Miss Drey

text: ¬†@Dinoboy Skittles¬† You're on the right track but no cigar
author: Augustin Gervasio

text: ¬†@Miss Drey¬† Doesn't take away the importance of the Amazon as a major carbon sink and biodiversity hotspot though.
author: BioMutarist

text:
Too much or too little oxygen is not good, not for humans anyway, we survived, thrived and evolved due to what our troposphere is made up of. Plants, fungi, animals and natural events/disasters lead us to where we are now, however humans are tipping the scale in a direction that will ultimately doom us and bring fourth a new era not made for us. Whether we survive it or not as a species depends on what we do now, planting plenty of trees is great, we have thrived and came from an overgrown planet before and we can again. "Too many trees" is a pathetic attempt to start an argument imo, there's no basis behind it.
At the end of the day i don't think anyone cares enough as it doesn't effect them right at this moment and the people that could afford too make massive impacts will generally never care or turn a blind eye.

However if we have people who live in a more inhospitable future Earth manage to survive and continue on humanity, i can imagine they will curse their ancestors laziness, stupidity and be ashamed that we took for granted even the air we currently breathe, you know, the stuff that sustains 99% of all known life on earth among many other things that anyone with an internet connection takes for granted.
author: Lachness

text:
It's not just about producing oxygen, but also the ability to capture carbon and algae doesn't do that at the scale that trees do.
For example, the period that we saw the biggest increase in oxygen levels, opposed to CO2, was in the Carboniferous, when trees first evolved... and algae already existed for hundreds of millions of years before that.

the real origin of the proverb ‚Äì a volume of moral writing by a quaker in 1951.  The aphorism then trickles through popular magazines, changing as it goes.  Ronald Reagan uses it in 1983.  But it seems to become a ‚ÄúGreek proverb‚Äù only in the hands of US congressmen in 1993. The Trueblood book was printed in 1951, earlier than any reference I can find.  And on p.58 we read our quote:



A man has made at least a start on discovering the meaning of human life when he plants shade trees under which he knows full well he will never sit.

text: Bull. Science shows that it is the oceans that are the lungs of the planet. Seaweed accounts for 54% of the world's oxygen production and the seas act as climate regulators on the planet. Oceans account between 50 and 80% of the oxygen in the atmosphere. For comparison, the terrestrial biosphere ‚Äî including forests ‚Äî stores only about 5% of the Earth‚Äôs carbon and produces most of the remainder of atmospheric oxygen. SO it is wrong to think that forests are the lungs of our planet. And trees also produce CO2. Lots of it.

text: We definitely must stop contributing to the cutting and burning of forests.  Like addressing the elephant in the room (an analogy I can still use because they're not extinct because of our exploits just yet):  Animal Agriculture.  The more animals you consume, the greater the demand, the more forests being cleared for grazing.  And before anyone brings up the "soy" argument ~70% of the worlds soy is fed to livestock, where as human consumption is around ~7% of the soy produced.  Less livestock = less intentional forest fires and clearings.

text: I don't see this as a rational way to combat climate change, although I'd love to see ecosystems restored.  If we planted a trillion trees, lots of CO2 would initially be removed from the atmosphere.  But once the new forests are established, no more CO2 is removed.  This is because trees die, and their carbon is released back into the atmosphere through microbial and fungi action.  So you end up back where you started, as long as you are continuing to burn fossil fuels.  The answer is to move away from burning carbon for energy.  Us solar, wind and nuclear, for example.

text: ‚ÄúEnergy storing carbohydrates‚Äù is misleading. When we use this energy that is ‚Äústored in carbohydrates‚Äù during cellular respiration/combustion reactions (which are the same in terms of chemical thermodynamics), most of the energy released is actually attributed to the relatively high energy bonds in oxygen molecules. The energy from the sun that is captured during photosynthesis is really ‚Äústored‚Äù in the oxygen molecules which can then convert this energy from chemical potential energy to usable energy when they undergo reactions such a combustion in which they produce molecules with lower energies such as water and carbon dioxide. Here are some American Chemical Society journal articles that provide evidence for this claim: https://doi.org/10.1021/acsomega.9b03352 and https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.jchemed.5b00333

text:
¬†@Bart Hartman¬† extinct no, but we could do with maybe lowering (or at least plateauing) population numbers and working more in line with nature, rather than against it all the time. Maybe learn to understand nature more rather than always thinking we know what‚Äôs right - even with good intentions we rarely do. 

This planet knows how to look after itself, how to regenerate - look at Chernobyl now with 30 years of little to no human intervention, or expanses of the ocean and islands that now don‚Äôt allow human visitations - it just needs us to stop taking and trying to alter things.
author: Monkeyboy1138

text: Yes, this 1000 times. The somewhat good news is that human population is set to plateau and then decline fairly sharply in the next couple of decades. author: Definitely not Polish Jerry

text:
¬†@Definitely not Polish Jerry¬† you say nature can kill ecosystems too, and that is true. But that is the natural shifting and changing of the planet that led to evolution events, which led to us and which will lead to other species once we‚Äôre gone. So, how is what we do different to what nature does? Well, nature takes hundreds of thousands of generations to change the climate which in turn allows species to evolve and adapt, whereas the same level of climate change has been created by humanity in just a few decades, with further worsening change in the decades to come. That‚Äôs nowhere near enough time for life on this planet to evolve and adapt. Remember every life form on this planet is part of this delicate balance other than humanity, we understand so little of how our world functions, even try to help it and continue to cause a domino reaction of problems down the line. It‚Äôs human arrogance to believe we‚Äôre anything other than just animals, that we‚Äôre in some way more important or that we can fix things.

The best and most helpful thing we can do for this planet, is to get our entire populations squeeze them in to vertical communities where we recycle everything, use vertical farming and do not step out of those communities. We‚Äôre so far out of the natural order of things now, that we need to divorce ourselves from the rest of the planet and just let it recover itself by itself.

text:
¬†@Jude _¬† not blaming, it's called reality of supply & demand. Where there's high demand, corporations, Brazilian government and farmers will happily supply at the cost of burning the Amazon, to feed China's growing middle class (clearing native forest to plant soy beans & raise cattle to export beef). 

Trying to blame corporations isn't going to stop the practice unless you stop the customers who buy from those corporations, and government who allows the destruction of the Amazon to continue. Remove the corporation and another one will take its place. Where there is high demand, there will be supply. 

China is Brazil's largest trading partner. In 2019 Brazil exported goods worth $63 billion US dollars to China - that's almost 30% of all Brazilian exports. The top 3 of exported goods to China are soybeans, beef and chicken. In 2019, Brazil was the world's biggest exporter of soybeans!

What are the¬†top global exports¬†of¬†Brazil? Soybeans, crude oil, iron ore, corn, and sulfate chemical woodpulp, exporting¬†mostly to¬†China¬†($63.5B), followed by United States ($30.5B). Does the US buy soy beans from Brazil? No, because the US farmers produce enough soy and beef themselves. The top categories of what US buys from Brazil in 2019 were: mineral fuels ($5.2 billion), iron and steel ($3.4 billion), aircraft ($2.7 billion), special other (returns) ($2.5 billion), and machinery ($2.4 billion).¬†

So if you can encourage Chinese consumers to stop buying beef, chicken and soy from Brazil, that might help the Amazon recover. Good luck. 

Sources:
https://ustr.gov/countries-regions/americas/brazil

https://oec.world/en/profile/country/bra#:~:text=Exports%3A%20The%20top%20exports%20of,and%20Japan%20(%245.58B).

http://www.worldstopexports.com/brazils-top-import-partners/

http://www.worldstopexports.com/brazils-top-import-partners/

The United States only has a population of approx. 330 mil, much lower than that of China‚Äôs, yet it still imports a large amount of products from Brazil. Measuring it per capita would be more appropriate. And also, you do realize that manufacturing machinery, let it be weapons or vehicles, produces a large amount of CO2 as well. Playing the blame game won‚Äôt help in this situation. Each nation has a responsibility to help mitigate and reduce the amount of CO2 that they release into the atmosphere. It is now about who takes the right steps, and who sits there and does nothing. text: Its not just trees! Grasslands, prairies, savannahs, etc can actually store more carbon in their soils than the same sized area of forest. Perennial grasses and forbs grow roots sometimes 12 feet into the ground, every millimeter of which is packed with carbon. Controlled burns and proper grazing practices actually speed up the rate in which these plants produce roots, near-exponentially increasing the rate of carbon sequestration.

text: ¬†@spectator¬† Peat bogs are a completely different thing, but yes, they do store huge amounts of carbon. What most people understand to be peat is the partially decomposed remains of sphagnum moss that grows in cold climates in Northern conifer forests, particularly common throughout Canada. Peat bogs are under major threat as they are regularly harvested for use in the horticultural industry to make potting soil. Because peat takes extreme amounts of time to regenerate, restoring these bogs for the purpose of carbon sequestration is not something that is very practical on the scale of a single human lifetime. Its one of those ecosystems that simply needs protecting than restoring.

text: ¬†@Wary of Extremes¬† People do not eat trees, but they do eat fruits from them. Trees also help prevent carbon dioxide glut, which, as you should know, carbon dioxide along with other elements reflect sunlight from the sun so that too much heat isn't trapped in the atmosphere. However, humans are producing exorbitant carbon dioxide from greenhouse gases, causing more heat to be trapped, also inducing higher temperatures and storms, et cetera. Therefore, some people try to spread awareness and reduce economic growth, but most people don't care. a huge disappointment. if you do not understand this or disprove, that is your blissful ignorance.
author: eleanor g.

text:
¬†@Wary of Extremes¬† It's the difference of decades vs. thousands of years. I've heard several estimates for when the next ice age could start, ranging from 1,500 years in the future to up to 20,000, and some sources suggest our current cycle most closely resembles a previous warm cycle that lasted 28,000 years, giving us around 16,000 left. Meanwhile, if we don't get to net zero emissions by 2050, there will be catastrophic effects on the ecosystem and conditions in many poor parts of the world will destabilize and get worse. Not to mention, there's theories that global warming could possibly speed up the next ice age, although that's far from the consensus. And if the more likely theory that climate change has pushed off the next ice age is true, then we've certainly already done enough. Even the low estimate of 1,500 years (and I think that estimate was based off of a non climate change earth), would be more than enough for humans to prepare for it, assuming we don't kill ourselves before that. I mean, in a thousand years it's possible a majority of humans won't even be on earth. 
And your claim that warmer weather and more C02 is beneficial to us doesn't make sense. There's estimates that our economy could shrink by 10% by 2100 if climate change isn't dealt with, and that's the effect on the U.S. Increased heat in parts of the world WILL cause massive economic losses and health epidemics and will lead to a massive refugee crisis where up to 300 million people may have to immigrate due to heat or rising sea levels. The U.S. will have to deal with over twice as many annual immigrants as now, and that's just from Central America. 
https://www.nytimes.com/2003/11/11/science/when-will-the-next-ice-age-begin.html
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ice_age#:~:text=Researchers%20used%20data%20on%20Earth's,usually%20begin%20within%201%2C500%20years.
https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2020/10/heat-human-rights-issue-21st-century/616693/
https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/07/23/magazine/climate-migration.html?action=click&module=Top%20Stories&pgtype=Homepage
author: Curran Frank

text:
¬†@Wary of Extremes¬† Environmentally, more C02 would be terrible for the ecosystem. That's already clear due to the number of animal and plant species becoming extinct or endangered. And I edited my old comment to go into the human cost of unmitigated climate change. That failed to include damages due to diseases spreading from warmer weather, premature deaths from poor air quality, which already causes 4.6 million deaths per year, increased damages from more powerful natural disasters, and a bunch of other factors. And like I said, we can easily adapt to an ice age- we might have the first commercial fusion reactor by 2050, and we're already growing a lot of food in doors. In a few hundred years our engineering skills could construct vast insulated areas where we maintain a warmer temperature for humans to live in, and maybe preserve certain valuable species. In a few thousand years we might have enough power to delay the ice age indefinitely. 
https://www.sciencedaily.com/terms/air_pollution.htm#:~:text=The%20World%20Health%20Organization%20estimates,pollution%20than%20to%20automobile%20accidents.
author: Curran Frank

text: ¬†@Wary of Extremes¬† The air pollution is due to the methods we use to that release C02 like coal plants, which release other dangerous compounds into the air. Air pollution is responsible for millions of deaths a year, and our energy sources are a big part of that. I'm aware we kill things directly, if climate change ramps up we'll be killing them at a rate comparable to a great extinction. Fusion just being 20 years away has more evidence now, and if it's 40 or 60 or 80 years, that still leaves 1,420 before the estimated ice age, and that's the shortest estimate that didn't factor in climate change. Plus, we could always use thorium reactors or hydro power, or space solar, fusion was just an example I used. There are ways to take C02 out that don't lead to mass killings. Planting more trees, like in this video, or implementing sustainable ocean farming practices like marine permaculture. These improve the native ecosystems while sequestering carbon. Plus ocean farming has a clear benefit towards humans, since it could cheaply feed billions of us with healthy foods like wild fish, kelp, oysters and seaweed. Also, you have yet to address the devastating costs to humans that I've mentioned. You know how Americans freak out over current rates? Imagine those being doubled
author: Curran Frank

text: ¬†@Peepee Train¬† It is very true that they're the major contributors of CO2 emissions. But a little from the average citizen is better than none. Also if consumers make switches in their habits (like using less electricity, reducing use of plastic, driving less by combining trips to the store) it creates less of a demand. The companies will be forced to produce less because it would hurt their profits to keep production as high.

text:
This is a lot more complicated than you think.

Bioplastic is a carbon sink. Sure, it does a lot of ecological damage, but the direct effect is carbon storage because it is literally made of carbon. So reducing plastic use is important, but it would do little for global warming.
Reducing water use is important but it has very little to do with global warming except for areas where it increases desertification, because deserts reflect light better than wetter ecosystems. Desertification causes global cooling.

I'd like to add some to your list though:
Buy green electricity.
Use less electricity if you can.
Live closer to your work so you commute less.
Buy local if you can.
Buy slow fashion instead of fast fashion.
Fly as little as possible, preferably not at all.
Use public transit if you can.
Bother your local politicians about creating public transit if you can't.

text: We‚Äôre too hung up on trees. What we need is biomass and surface area correct? Then what about invasive species like kudzu? With minimal effort it can be nurtured to make footholds and spread even in deserts. Almost every part is edible and it can grow where other food crops cannot. Since it spreads so readily and quickly, it shouldn‚Äôt have much trouble laying a layer of top soil either. Invasive species like kudzu would still be a threat to strangling and starving out other species trying to take root in that new layer, but it should be perfectly viable as a shocktrooper.

author: Jonathan Herring

text:
We're at a dire point in history where that might is a much smaller risk than the chance we hit the CO2 point where clouds stop forming. Yes, really, literally. There is a concentration of CO2 at which clouds to cease forming. We need to act really quickly, and that includes takings smaller risks, because we REALLY do not want to hit that point. Trees create clouds (they allow water to evaporate into the atmosphere) so it seems like a good counter balance. 
Incidentally the not-forming of clouds wouldn't be uniform, but water usage will become impossible to manage if we get to that point because less less clouds means less rain.

text:
"The world is being poisoned very slowly. The rivers are being polluted, the oceans are being polluted, the lakes are dying. Nature is being destroyed. We are exploiting the earth so much that sooner or later we will not be able to live on it. We are not behaving well with nature.

Our whole approach is wrong, it is destructive. We only take from the earth, and we never give anything back. We only exploit nature. The ecology is broken, the circulation is broken; we are not living in a perfect circle, and nature is a perfect circle: if you take from one hand and you give from another, you don‚Äôt destroy it. But we are doing it: we only go on taking, and all the resources are being spent. But this poisoning is happening slowly, slowly. You don‚Äôt see it happening because it takes a long time. And then there are politicians who go on gathering more and more atomic weapons ‚Äì more atom bombs, more hydrogen bombs, super-hydrogen bombs ‚Äì as if man has decided to commit suicide" - osho

text:
Planting trees is at best a short term measure to slow climate change, gassing the atmosphere is another (though potentially far more effective) way to slow or stop the warming, but cutting emissions or removing the carbon long term is the only long term solution. Trees also use water and create water vapour so as the video points out may do more harm than good(water vapour being by far the primary greenhouse gas). Ocean seeding would be far more effective than planting trees, it would sequester carbon permanently while increasing fish stocks. The only other realistic solution might be if fussion power becomes possible power may be so plentiful that we can pull the carbon back out of the atmosphere and turn it into solid building materials (yes this is possible, just uses too much power to be viable at the moment). 
The unfortunate truth we have to accept is that carbon emission won't drop until the developing world catches up and that's going to take decades at best.
author: Matt TheChosen

text: ¬†@Pedroal√≠ Tovar¬† Isn't that destroying ecosystems? We love to consume; whether that be something physical or information. Production-generated value contradicts our need to reconcile ourselves to nature. This video points to myopia as a significant source of human-related problems, yet advocates for more research, more production, more information, more myopia, more. Mother Nature every day tells us she's had enough. Climate Change, Coronaviruses, collapsing ecosystems all dictate that less innovation reconcile us to her. Yet we refuse to concede our victories over her in our blind credence to intelligence. We falsely believe that science is on the side of logic, of nature, while neglecting its history. Stupidity stumbles forward; pressing us against impending doom. Continuing to advantage our surplus over our omnipotent mother yields loss. This reasoning has brought us to this predicament. It may have temporarily alleviated us from struggle, from a relation foreign to every other organism, yet it will never free us from her laws. Equilibrium must be achieved.
author: M G104

text: What can the average person do then? I was ready to volunteer on tree planting lol.
author: ToxicFyre

text: ¬†@ToxicFyre¬† Revert back to primitivism. Mother Nature is the best designer, so we need to go back to our native ecosystems and integrate ourselves into the local. We forget that extreme myopia plagues us. Our atypical economic structure contradicts equilibrium.
author: M G104

text: ¬†@M G104¬† While I agree that our modern society needs way more interaction with nature. Technology has been with us since we have invented agriculture. We could find a good way to balance these two elements. What do you think?
author: ToxicFyre

text: ¬†@ToxicFyre¬† Funny. Nature was in balance until human civilizations began. Agricultural surplus, urban production and transportation begat cities; an environment that brought mankind out of nature, apart from the laws nature enforces to keep organisms in equilibrium. Technology and innovation separate us from these struggles, enabling us to transcend the local ecosystems and disproportionally take resources necessary for life to thrive. I believe integrating ourselves back into the local, giving up technology and our standard of living is the only way to reconcile humanity to nature.
author: M G104

text: ¬†@M G104¬† But even though humanity has been at odds with the environment this whole time doesn't mean we can't create a technological civilization which is in balance with it, no? I mean, there's no law of nature that says so, just our track record.
author: ToxicFyre

text: ¬†@ToxicFyre¬† Technology is a product of civilization. Solar panels, wind turbines, hydroelectricity all require unsustainable production. They are alien to their local ecosystem, just as we are. Have you watched "Primitive Technology?" That's the only sustainable technology- 100% recyclable, renewable. Innovation removes us from nature. Equilibrium will only be achieved on a local level, limiting our resources and thereby, our technology. Can't you see that? Our myopic solutions to Mother Nature's perceived problems become problems in and of themselves. I came upon these conclusions after reading the second chapter of David Orr's "The Nature of Design: Ecology, Culture and Human Intention."
author: M G104

text: ¬†@M G104¬† Thanks for your reply. I'll check these things out and answer afterwards, cheers!

author: Hardy Lin

text:
A lot of people believe in climate change but don't believe in the solutions. Planting trees can't fix the problem, indeed it may make it worse, solar and wind power have serious environmental issues of their own and people irrationality fear nuclear. Even cutting emissions completely today would only reduce the severity of the outcome. There are potential solutions, but they aren't popular because they don't sound as green. Current nuclear would be more environmentally friendly and far cleaner than current renewables, fussion power if it finally works properly (hopefully within the next decade) will open up lots of possibilities including pulling the carbon back out of the atmosphere and turning it into building materials, yet governments give it so little attention. Luckily fussion is now being tackled by multiple private and University backed startups so has been advancing far far faster than it was before. Hopefully in a decade we will have solved the issue of climate change and get back to focusing of the other environmental issues that often get ignored now. 
Unfortunately the really big issue is going to be the developing world problem, Africa is about to do something similar to China and is likely to dramatically increase output of not just greenhouse gases but all sorts of pollutants. To me that's going to be a far bigger mess than the current climate change issues will turn out.

Did you even know there was more forest being burned in Africa at the time people were crying about the Amazon or that on average over the last decade less of the Amazon was burnt than normal or that China plants billions of trees each year(has for a very long time) that Canada plants hundreds of millions, as do many other countries.
If anything trees may be part of the reason why the earth is warming due to the amount of water vapour they are adding to the atmosphere and because the work as heatsinks at night.
author: Matt TheChosen

text:
¬†@Matt TheChosen¬† 
Nope.....

"Scientists have long debated about the impact on global climate of water evaporated from vegetation. New research concludes that evaporated water helps cool the earth as a whole, not just the local area of evaporation, demonstrating that evaporation of water from trees and lakes could have a cooling effect on the entire atmosphere. These findings have major implications for land-use decision making."

https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2011/09/110914161729.htm
author: Robert Pruitt

text:
¬†@Matt TheChosen¬† 
And yes, the world is greening.

That's irrelevant.

LOTS of plants like the warmer temperatures. But even the vast majority of those heat loving plants have a limit of just a few degrees warmer than the "average" they're used to.

But the plants we rely on for our food, aren't really in the "heat loving" category......

See the problem?

Climate change and global warming ARE real. 

Even ExxonMobil has come out and admitted their own scientific research, going back several decades, "mirrors" the mainstream science.

author: Rainer Tristan

text:
Most people don't realise that China has been planting huge amounts of trees for decades now. Since the program started over 60 billion trees have been planted. Granted it's a corrupt country and bad things happened like cutting down a forest to plant trees or planting twice as many trees as the land could handle, but the result has been China is far more green today than it was back in the 70's. NASA has a series of satellite images showing the vaste change over the years.
Funny what the media choose to tell people and what they choose to leave out. Indeed the whole world has far more trees today than it did for at least 50 years, yet we only hear about things like a tiny fraction of the Amazon burning.

text: Certainly agree with you¬†@HERMIT¬† as of 2018.  But not sure that this is still true now in 2020.  The World Intellectual Property Organization, which oversees a system for countries to share recognition of patents, said 58,990 applications were filed from China last year, beating out the United States which filed 57,840.  This is the first time since WIPO was set up that the US was not in first place.  It's worrying to see how far behind China the US is in sectors like 5G telecoms and AI is another area where they seem to be leaping ahead.

text: ¬†@blank¬† WORD. my school makes us write heaps of essays titled "ways to save the environment" and "importance of planting trees", and students are expected to vomit out the usual 3Rs concept and "plant more trees to save the earth!" with a only a basic generic understanding of how these methods actually help our environment. my syllabus has never taught me about the difficulty humanity faces in forest restoration (ecosystem imbalance), or the (potentially) resulting biochemical emissions that might take place, causing further acceleration in global warming. imagine being told your whole life that planting trees is good for the earth, but then finding out you might actually be unintentionally hurting it by doing so. i'm honestly very disappointed in my education system, and everyone else's.
